body:
Comment 7: 
The CL only hides the 6c generated warnings for files that are entirely generated by
SWIG.  There is absolutely no user written code in these files.  If you take a look, you
will see that the files are nothing but variable declarations.  So there is really no
cost to hiding the warnings, as there is absolutely nothing that the user can do to fix
them.

Yes, at some point SWIG needs to stop supporting old versions of Go.  In fact SWIG no
longer works with Go 1.0.3.  And, yes, exposing the version in runtime.h is probably a
good idea.  But SWIG should support old versions of Go as long as possible.  Go 1.1 is
not all that old--it came out less than two years ago.  There are certainly systems
still running it.  The usual SWIG philosophy is to support old versions for as long as
possible; for example, current SWIG supports very old versions of Python.

The version of SWIG that Go requires and the version of Go that SWIG requires are two
entirely different things.  We don't want to force the two independent projects to move
forward in lockstep.  In particular it would be nice if new versions of Go did not
require a new version of SWIG.  Unfortunately the significant changes in Go 1.4 for
supporting an improved GC did not permit supporting old versions of SWIG.

The truth is that I made a mistake in the original SWIG port: I had SWIG replicate the
operations of cgo, rather than having SWIG invoke cgo.  This was an understandable
mistake since the SWIG support was written before the go tool existed.  However, it
would be better if SWIG generated input for cgo, so that cgo could take responsibility
for the Go/C interface.  This would in essence mean that SWIG would generate a C
interface for C++ code.  Unfortunately this is of course a significant change and I
don't anticipate having any time to work on it.
